name: Jazz
description: Originating in African American communities in the Southern United States around the turn of the 20th century, building on New Orleans Brass Band ensemble and influences from Ragtime and Blues to become a very popular style by the emergence of Swing in the 1930s.

sub_genres.name: Afro-Jazz
sub_genres.description: African-styled percussion and rhythms.

sub_genres.name: Arabic Jazz
sub_genres.description: Blending of Arabic Music and Jazz.

sub_genres.name: Avant-Garde Jazz
sub_genres.description: Combines traditional or mainstream Jazz stylings with non-traditional techniques of avant-garde art music by experimenting with characteristics such as rhythm, harmony, structure, melody, and instrumentation.

sub_genres.name: Bebop
sub_genres.description: Fast tempos, improvisation, melodic chromaticism, and complex harmonies and chord progressions.

sub_genres.name: Big Band
sub_genres.description: Commonly associated with the golden era of Swing in the 1930s and 1940s, performed by a large ensemble including brass, woodwinds, and usually a rhythm section.

sub_genres.name: British Dance Band
sub_genres.description: Came from the dancehalls of the 1920s and 1930s, combining a British take on Jazz with the Music Hall tradition.

sub_genres.name: Bulawayo Jazz
sub_genres.description: Emerged from the city of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe in the early 1950s, led by the alto sax and accompanied by ensembles.

sub_genres.name: Cape Jazz
sub_genres.description: Developed parallel to American Jazz in the early 20th century, named for its origin in Cape Town, South Africa.

sub_genres.name: Cartoon Music
sub_genres.description: Zany and uptempo; incorporates elements of Western Classical Music and Modern Classical into frantic Big Band arrangements, playfully chaotic to match the on-screen actions of Cartoon characters and the beat of their movements.

sub_genres.name: Chamber Jazz
sub_genres.description: Made by mostly small acoustic-based ensembles with emphasized improvisation and influenced by Neoclassicism and Traditional Folk Music.

sub_genres.name: Cool Jazz
sub_genres.description: Developed in the late 1940s alongside and in response to Bebop, featuring a more restrained, emotionally "cool" style.

sub_genres.name: Crime Jazz
sub_genres.description: Gritty, moody style that emerged in the mid-1950s to accompany film noir movies and hard-boiled detective/crime-themed TV shows.

sub_genres.name: Dark Jazz
sub_genres.description: Melancholic and gloomy Film noir-inspired atmosphere and influence from Crime Jazz and Dark Ambient.

sub_genres.name: Dixieland
sub_genres.description: Developed in New Orleans in the 1910s, incorporating influences from Ragtime and Blues into cacophonous, polyphonic arrangements with instruments trading places between accompaniment and soloist.

sub_genres.name: ECM Style Jazz
sub_genres.description: Primarily associated with ECM Records, combining elements of Jazz Fusion with the subdued atmosphere of Cool Jazz and the Western Classical Music bent of Third Stream.

sub_genres.name: Ethio-Jazz
sub_genres.description: Unique blend of traditional Ethiopic Music and Jazz.

sub_genres.name: Flamenco Jazz
sub_genres.description: Combination of Jazz with Flamenco nuevo, the contemporary style of Flamenco, which was pioneered in the late 1960s.

sub_genres.name: Hard Bop
sub_genres.description: A continuation of Bebop that reintroduces more traditional African-American musical features, such as bluesy melodies, slow to medium tempos, and a more groove-oriented sound, while retaining the expressive improvisation.

sub_genres.name: Indo Jazz
sub_genres.description: Fuses the various musical traditions of the Indian subcontinent with jazzy musical structures.

sub_genres.name: Jazz Fusion
sub_genres.description: Near-universal usage of electric guitars and keyboards coupled with influences from genres such as Rock, Rhythm & Blues, Funk, and Traditional Folk Music, and a relative degree of harmonic simplicity.

sub_genres.name: Jazz Poetry
sub_genres.description: Emerged in the 1920s, incorporating the style and rhythms of Jazz as both art forms spread throughout African-American communities in the United States.

sub_genres.name: Jazz manouche
sub_genres.description: Combines Jazz with several aspects of Romani Folk Music.

sub_genres.name: Jazz-Funk
sub_genres.description: Jazz highly influenced by Funk.

sub_genres.name: Kr√©yol djaz
sub_genres.description: Combines Jazz with various styles of French Caribbean Music.

sub_genres.name: Latin Jazz
sub_genres.description: Fusion with Latin American rhythms, especially those of African origin.

sub_genres.name: Marabi
sub_genres.description: South African Jazz with origins in the 1920s and rooted in traditional South African music.

sub_genres.name: Modal Jazz
sub_genres.description: Utilizes musical modes as harmonic framework over traditionally used chord progressions.

sub_genres.name: Post-Bop
sub_genres.description: Grew out of Hard Bop in the early to mid-1960s incorporating certain untraditional elements inspired largely in part from Avant-Garde Jazz, Modal Jazz and eventually, Free Jazz, such as non-diatonic chord progressions, irregular rhythms and amelodic forms.

sub_genres.name: Smooth Jazz
sub_genres.description: Simple melodies and slick production influenced by Pop and R&B.

sub_genres.name: Soul Jazz
sub_genres.description: Appeared during the 1950s when Gospel, Rhythm & Blues and later Soul started to influence the style of prolific Jazz musicians.

sub_genres.name: Spiritual Jazz
sub_genres.description: Emerged in the 1960s, marked by a mixture of Jazz with approximations of ethnic styles, religious music of non-Christian traditions, and the ecstatic, transcendental aspects of Free Jazz.

sub_genres.name: Spy Music
sub_genres.description: Meant to evoke the action and drama of Spy films.

sub_genres.name: Stride
sub_genres.description: Early form of Ragtime-derived Jazz with improvisational tendencies; named for the performers' left hand "striding" across the piano keyboard.

sub_genres.name: Sweet Jazz
sub_genres.description: Early form developed by white bandleaders and highly popular with white audiences in the 1920s, emphasizing arrangements and strong melodies with a straighter rhythmic feel, de-emphasizing improvisation compared to "hot" Dixieland.

sub_genres.name: Swing
sub_genres.description: Distinctive rhythm and large backing rhythm section over which solos are performed.

sub_genres.name: Third Stream
sub_genres.description: A fusion of Jazz and Western Classical Music, with improvisation as a vital component.

sub_genres.name: Vocal Jazz
sub_genres.description: Focused on vocals, generally using a more traditional, poppy strong structure and reducing the role of improvisation.

sub_genres.name: West Coast Jazz
sub_genres.description: Laidback style of jazz related aesthetically to Cool Jazz, developed by musicians based in Los Angeles and San Francisco, California in the 1950s.
